title: Matrix over division ring having one sided inverse is invertible
body: I want to see if there is any elementary way to prove the following assertion about matrices over division rings (such as not using Wedderburn's theory or tensoring techniques). body: Here's the question- Find the maximum area of an isosceles triangle inscribed in the ellipse #(start)# #(v!x,[n,a],-)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,/,n,-)# #(v!x,/,n)# #(/,v!a,n,n)# #(/,v!a,n)# #(v!a,[n,a],nn)# #(v!a,[n,a])# #(v!a,+,n,nn)# #(v!a,+,n)# #(+,v!y,n,nnn)# #(+,v!y,n)# #(v!y,[n,a],nnnn)# #(v!y,[n,a])# #(v!y,/,n,nnnn)# #(v!y,/,n)# #(/,v!b,n,nnnnn)# #(/,v!b,n)# #(v!b,[n,a],6n)# #(v!b,[n,a])# #(v!b,=,n,6n)# #(v!b,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,7n)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,8n)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!b,n!2,a,6n)# #(v!b,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,6n1a)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!y,n!2,a,nnnn)# #(v!y,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnnna)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nna,a,nnnn}# #{n!2,nna,a}# #(v!a,n!2,a,nn)# #(v!a,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nna)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nnnna,a,nn}# #{n!2,nnnna,a}# #{n!2,nna,a,nn}# #{n!2,nna,a}# #{/,nnnn,n}# #{/,nnnn}# #(v!x,n!2,a,-)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,a)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,6n1a,a,-}# #{n!2,6n1a,a}# #{n!2,nnnna,a,-}# #{n!2,nnnna,a}# #{n!2,nna,a,-}# #{n!2,nna,a}# #(end)#. My teacher solved it by considering two arbitrary points on the ellipse to be vertices of the triangle, being #(start)# #(m!()1x2,v!a,w,-)# #(m!()1x2,v!a,w)# #(v!a,[n,e],w)# #(v!a,[n,e])# #(v!a,v!cos,n,w)# #(v!a,v!cos,n)# #(v!cos,v!θ,n,wn)# #(v!cos,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,!0,wnn)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(v!a,v!b,e,w)# #(v!a,v!b,e)# #(v!b,v!sin,n,we)# #(v!b,v!sin,n)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n,wen)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,!0,wenn)# #(v!θ,!0)# #{v!θ,nn,enn,w}# #{v!θ,nn,enn}# #(end)# and #(start)# #(m!()1x2,v!a,w,-)# #(m!()1x2,v!a,w)# #(v!a,[n,e],w)# #(v!a,[n,e])# #(v!a,v!cos,n,w)# #(v!a,v!cos,n)# #(v!cos,v!θ,n,wn)# #(v!cos,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,!0,wnn)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(v!a,-,e,w)# #(v!a,-,e)# #(-,v!b,n,we)# #(-,v!b,n)# #(v!b,v!sin,n,wen)# #(v!b,v!sin,n)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n,wenn)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,!0,wennn)# #(v!θ,!0)# #{v!θ,nn,ennn,w}# #{v!θ,nn,ennn}# #(end)#. (Let's just say #(start)# #(v!θ,!0,-)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(end)# is theta) and then proceeded with the derivative tests(which i understood) But, he didn't indicate what our #(start)# #(v!θ,!0,-)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(end)# was,and declared that these points always lie on an ellipse. Why so? And even if they do, what's the guarantee that points of such a form will be our required vertices? One more thing, I'd appreciate it if you could suggest another way of solving this problem. Thank you!

But the appearance of the combination is non-obvious.

In how many ways can these assignments be done?  I know that for each section (A,B,C,D) I should add a () and as long as every section must get a new employee we should start like this: #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w])# #(m!()1x1,n!4,a,-)# #(m!()1x1,n!4,a)# #(n!4,!0,a)# #(n!4,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,+,n,w)# #(v!x,+,n)# #(+,v!x,n,wn)# #(+,v!x,n)# #(v!x,[n,a],wnn)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,/,n,wnn)# #(v!x,/,n)# #(/,n!2,n,wnnn)# #(/,n!2,n)# #(n!2,!,n,wnnnn)# #(n!2,!,n)# #(!,+,n,1w5n)# #(!,+,n)# #(+,v!x,n,1w6n)# #(+,v!x,n)# #(v!x,[n,a],1w7n)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,/,n,1w7n)# #(v!x,/,n)# #(/,n!3,n,1w8n)# #(/,n!3,n)# #(n!3,!,n,1w9n)# #(n!3,!,n)# #(!,+,n,1w10n)# #(!,+,n)# #(+,v!…,n,1w11n)# #(+,v!…,n)# #(v!…,!0,1w12n)# #(v!…,!0)# #(v!x,n!3,a,1w7n)# #(v!x,n!3,a)# #(n!3,!0,1w7n1a)# #(n!3,!0)# #{n!3,nn,a,1w7n}# #{n!3,nn,a}# #{+,nnnnn,1w6n}# #{+,nnnnn}# #{!,nnnnn,1w5n}# #{!,nnnnn}# #{/,nnnnn,wnnn}# #{/,nnnnn}# #(v!x,n!2,a,wnn)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,wnna)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nn,a,wnn}# #{n!2,nn,a}# #{v!x,nnnnn,wnn}# #{v!x,nnnnn}# #{+,10n,wn}# #{+,10n}# #{+,nnnnn,wn}# #{+,nnnnn}# #{v!x,7n,w}# #{v!x,7n}# #{v!x,nn,w}# #{v!x,nn}# #(end)# then if we look  it's #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w])# #(m!()1x1,n!4,a,-)# #(m!()1x1,n!4,a)# #(n!4,!0,a)# #(n!4,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w)# #(v!e,[n,a],w)# #(v!e,[n,a])# #(v!e,-,n,w)# #(v!e,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,wn)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,wnn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!e,v!x,a,w)# #(v!e,v!x,a)# #(v!x,!0,wa)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. After this step I don't know what to do.

Give a combinatorial proof that #(start)# #(∑,[n,o,u],-)# #(∑,[n,o,u])# #(∑,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(∑,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,f!,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,=,n,nn)# #(f!,=,n)# #(=,n!2,n,nnn)# #(=,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!n,a,nnnn)# #(n!2,v!n,a)# #(v!n,!0,nnnna)# #(v!n,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,nn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!2,u,nn)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,v!i,a,nnu)# #(n!2,v!i,a)# #(v!i,!0,nnua)# #(v!i,!0)# #{n!2,nn,u,nn}# #{n!2,nn,u}# #(m!()1x1,f!,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[o,u],nw)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!n,o,nw)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,+,n,nwo)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,nwon)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,nwonn)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,nua,wonn,n}# #{v!i,nua,wonn}# #{v!n,nnna,wo,n}# #{v!n,nnna,wo}# #(f!,v!i,u,nw)# #(f!,v!i,u)# #(v!i,!0,nwu)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,nua,wu,n}# #{v!i,nua,wu}# #{v!i,onn,u,nw}# #{v!i,onn,u}# #{f!,n,w,n}# #{f!,n,w}# #(∑,v!n,o,-)# #(∑,v!n,o)# #(v!n,!0,o)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nnnna,o,-}# #{v!n,nnnna,o}# #{v!n,nwo,o,-}# #{v!n,nwo,o}# #(∑,v!i,u,-)# #(∑,v!i,u)# #(v!i,=,n,u)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,n!0,n,un)# #(=,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,unn)# #(n!0,!0)# #{=,nnn,un,-}# #{=,nnn,un}# #{v!i,nnua,u,-}# #{v!i,nnua,u}# #{v!i,nwonn,u,-}# #{v!i,nwonn,u}# #{v!i,nwu,u,-}# #{v!i,nwu,u}# #(end)#.  I'm not sure if Pascal's identity is useful here. Or perhaps there is a way involving binary strings? #(start)# #(n!2,v!n,a,-)# #(n!2,v!n,a)# #(v!n,!0,a)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# is the number of binary strings of length #(start)# #(v!n,!0,-)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)#, so if there was some way to decompose these strings into disjoint sets #(start)# #(v!b,v!i,b,-)# #(v!b,v!i,b)# #(v!i,!0,b)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# with cardinality #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,f!,n,-)# #(m!()1x1,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],n)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,n)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,no)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!2,u,n)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,v!i,a,nu)# #(n!2,v!i,a)# #(v!i,!0,nua)# #(v!i,!0)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[o,u],w)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!n,o,w)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,+,n,wo)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,won)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,wonn)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,nua,wonn,-}# #{v!i,nua,wonn}# #(f!,v!i,u,w)# #(f!,v!i,u)# #(v!i,!0,wu)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,nua,wu,-}# #{v!i,nua,wu}# #{v!i,onn,u,w}# #{v!i,onn,u}# #{f!,n,w,-}# #{f!,n,w}# #(end)#, a proof using that method might work. #(start)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[o,u],w)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!n,o,w)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,+,n,wo)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,won)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,wonn)# #(v!i,!0)# #(f!,v!i,u,w)# #(f!,v!i,u)# #(v!i,!0,wu)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,onn,u,w}# #{v!i,onn,u}# #(end)# is the number of binary strings of length #(start)# #(v!n,+,n,-)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,n)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,nn)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# with exactly #(start)# #(v!i,!0,-)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# ones, since one can choose #(start)# #(v!i,!0,-)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# of the #(start)# #(v!n,+,n,-)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,n)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,nn)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# positions to be ones in #(start)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[o,u],w)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!n,o,w)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,+,n,wo)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,v!i,n,won)# #(+,v!i,n)# #(v!i,!0,wonn)# #(v!i,!0)# #(f!,v!i,u,w)# #(f!,v!i,u)# #(v!i,!0,wu)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,onn,u,w}# #{v!i,onn,u}# #(end)# ways and make the rest zeroes in one way. Then we divide by the number of binary strings of length #(start)# #(v!i,!0,-)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)#, though I'm not sure how to deduce the combinatorial significance of this. I'm most likely thinking of this the wrong way.

Does component 2 also admit a parameterization?  To clarify: Component 2 is a path so of course it abstractly admits a parameterization, but I'm asking if there is a parametrization that we can actually write down algebraically in terms of elementary functions. title: Sards theorem for polynomial
body: I'm having some struggles with an aspect about something apparently trivial about Sard's theorem, but couldn't find anything online.  Let #(start)# #(v!f,!0,-)# #(v!f,!0)# #(end)# be a polynomial.  According to Sard's theorem, the image #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!z,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!z,w)# #(v!z,!0,nw)# #(v!z,!0)# #(end)# of the set of critical values  #(start)# #(v!z,=,n,-)# #(v!z,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,∈,n,nnw)# #(v!a,∈,n)# #(∈,v!x,n,nnwn)# #(∈,v!x,n)# #(v!x,:,n,nnwnn)# #(v!x,:,n)# #(:,v!f,n,2n1w3n)# #(:,v!f,n)# #(v!f,[n,a],2n1w4n)# #(v!f,[n,a])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,2n1w4n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],2n1w5n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,2n1w5n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!0,n,2n1w6n)# #(=,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,2n1w7n)# #(n!0,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,2n1w5n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,2n1w5n1w)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!f,′,a,2n1w4n)# #(v!f,′,a)# #(′,!0,2n1w4n1a)# #(′,!0)# #{v!a,5n1w,nnw}# #{v!a,5n1w}# #{=,1n1w6n,n}# #{=,1n1w6n}# #(end)# has measure zero. title: Definition of Equivalence Relation
body: I was going through the text "Discrete Mathematics and its Application" by Kenneth Rosen (5th Edition) where I am across the definition of equivalence relation and felt that it is one sided.     Definition: A relation on a set A is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.   Now let us analyze the situation of what equivalence is meant to us intuitively.  Let there be a binary relation #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# defined on a set #(start)# #(v!a,!0,-)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)#. Now we suppose that #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# be reflexive, symmetric and transitive.  So we have for #(start)# #(v!a,comma,n,-)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!b,n,n)# #(comma,v!b,n)# #(v!b,comma,n,nn)# #(v!b,comma,n)# #(comma,v!c,n,nnn)# #(comma,v!c,n)# #(v!c,∈,n,nnnn)# #(v!c,∈,n)# #(∈,v!a,n,nnnnn)# #(∈,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,6n)# #(v!a,!0)# #{comma,nn,n}# #{comma,nn}# #(end)#    #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!a,n,n)# #(v!r,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nn,-}# #{v!a,nn}# #(end)# (by the reflexive property of R) if #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!b,n,n)# #(v!r,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# then #(start)# #(v!b,v!r,n,-)# #(v!b,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!a,n,n)# #(v!r,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)#  (by the symmetric property of R) if #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!b,n,n)# #(v!r,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!b,v!r,n,-)# #(v!b,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# then #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# (by the transitive property of R)   Intuitively we can satisfy ourselves with the fact that the above are the necessary conditions for #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# to be equivalent. So "if #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# is reflexive, symmetric and transitive, then #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# is an equivalence relation"  Now working our intuition for equivalence relation #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# we note the following.  Let #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# be an equivalence relation on a set A, then for #(start)# #(v!a,comma,n,-)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!b,n,n)# #(comma,v!b,n)# #(v!b,comma,n,nn)# #(v!b,comma,n)# #(comma,v!c,n,nnn)# #(comma,v!c,n)# #(v!c,∈,n,nnnn)# #(v!c,∈,n)# #(∈,v!a,n,nnnnn)# #(∈,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,6n)# #(v!a,!0)# #{comma,nn,n}# #{comma,nn}# #(end)# we have,   #(start)# #(v!a,∼,n,-)# #(v!a,∼,n)# #(∼,v!a,n,n)# #(∼,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nn,-}# #{v!a,nn}# #(end)# (by the intuitive knowledge of what #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# means) if #(start)# #(v!a,∼,n,-)# #(v!a,∼,n)# #(∼,v!b,n,n)# #(∼,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# then #(start)# #(v!b,∼,n,-)# #(v!b,∼,n)# #(∼,v!a,n,n)# #(∼,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# (by the intuitive knowledge of what #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# means) if #(start)# #(v!a,∼,n,-)# #(v!a,∼,n)# #(∼,v!b,n,n)# #(∼,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!b,∼,n,-)# #(v!b,∼,n)# #(∼,v!c,n,n)# #(∼,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# then #(start)# #(v!a,∼,n,-)# #(v!a,∼,n)# #(∼,v!c,n,n)# #(∼,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# (by the intuitive knowledge of what #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# means)   Now we see that (1) implies #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# is reflexive, (2) implies that #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# is symmetric and (3) implies that #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# is transitive.  So we have "if #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# is an equivalent relation then #(start)# #(∼,!0,-)# #(∼,!0)# #(end)# is reflexive, symmetric and transitive"  From the two intuitive implications we can conclude that A relation on a set A is called an equivalence relation if and only if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. and not what the book says. This definition makes quite sense unlike the book definition which says that if #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# fails to be either reflexive or symmetric or transitive then #(start)# #(v!r,!0,-)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# may or may not be an equivalence relation, which after all gives a weird feeling.  Correct me if my logic is wrong.

It is easy to show that #(start)# #(v!m,!0,-)# #(v!m,!0)# #(end)# is a sugroup of #(start)# #(v!g,!0,-)# #(v!g,!0)# #(end)# and the number of elements of #(start)# #(v!m,!0,-)# #(v!m,!0)# #(end)# must be a power of #(start)# #(n!2,!0,-)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)#.     I want to prove that the product of the elements of #(start)# #(v!g,!0,-)# #(v!g,!0)# #(end)# (which in this case is equal to the product of the elements of #(start)# #(v!m,!0,-)# #(v!m,!0)# #(end)#) is not the identity element #(start)# #(v!e,!0,-)# #(v!e,!0)# #(end)#, if and only if ##(start)# #(v!m,=,n,-)# #(v!m,=,n)# #(=,n!2,n,n)# #(=,n!2,n)# #(n!2,!0,nn)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# (this means that there is only one element with order #(start)# #(n!2,!0,-)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)#). The case ##(start)# #(v!m,=,n,-)# #(v!m,=,n)# #(=,n!4,n,n)# #(=,n!4,n)# #(n!4,!0,nn)# #(n!4,!0)# #(end)# is easy. But what about ##(start)# #(v!m,=,n,-)# #(v!m,=,n)# #(=,n!8,n,n)# #(=,n!8,n)# #(n!8,!0,nn)# #(n!8,!0)# #(end)#? If we have the elements #(start)# #(v!e,comma,n,-)# #(v!e,comma,n)# #(comma,v!a,n,n)# #(comma,v!a,n)# #(v!a,comma,n,nn)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!b,n,nnn)# #(comma,v!b,n)# #(v!b,comma,n,nnnn)# #(v!b,comma,n)# #(comma,v!c,n,nnnnn)# #(comma,v!c,n)# #(v!c,comma,n,6n)# #(v!c,comma,n)# #(comma,v!d,n,7n)# #(comma,v!d,n)# #(v!d,comma,n,8n)# #(v!d,comma,n)# #(comma,v!f,n,9n)# #(comma,v!f,n)# #(v!f,comma,n,10n)# #(v!f,comma,n)# #(comma,v!g,n,11n)# #(comma,v!g,n)# #(v!g,comma,n,12n)# #(v!g,comma,n)# #(comma,v!h,n,13n)# #(comma,v!h,n)# #(v!h,!0,14n)# #(v!h,!0)# #{comma,nn,11n}# #{comma,nn}# #{comma,nnnn,9n}# #{comma,nnnn}# #{comma,nn,9n}# #{comma,nn}# #{comma,6n,7n}# #{comma,6n}# #{comma,nnnn,7n}# #{comma,nnnn}# #{comma,nn,7n}# #{comma,nn}# #{comma,8n,nnnnn}# #{comma,8n}# #{comma,6n,nnnnn}# #{comma,6n}# #{comma,nnnn,nnnnn}# #{comma,nnnn}# #{comma,nn,nnnnn}# #{comma,nn}# #{comma,10n,nnn}# #{comma,10n}# #{comma,8n,nnn}# #{comma,8n}# #{comma,6n,nnn}# #{comma,6n}# #{comma,nnnn,nnn}# #{comma,nnnn}# #{comma,nn,nnn}# #{comma,nn}# #{comma,12n,n}# #{comma,12n}# #{comma,10n,n}# #{comma,10n}# #{comma,8n,n}# #{comma,8n}# #{comma,6n,n}# #{comma,6n}# #{comma,nnnn,n}# #{comma,nnnn}# #{comma,nn,n}# #{comma,nn}# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!a,v!b,n,-)# #(v!a,v!b,n)# #(v!b,=,n,n)# #(v!b,=,n)# #(=,v!c,n,nn)# #(=,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nnn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!d,v!f,n,-)# #(v!d,v!f,n)# #(v!f,=,n,n)# #(v!f,=,n)# #(=,v!g,n,nn)# #(=,v!g,n)# #(v!g,!0,nnn)# #(v!g,!0)# #(end)#, the product would be #(start)# #(v!h,!0,-)# #(v!h,!0)# #(end)# which is impossible considering my claim. I would consider these 'appearances' of #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!π,n,-)# #(f!,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,-)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!6,u,-)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,!0,u)# #(n!6,!0)# #(end)# to be redundant and ask that they not be mentioned unless you have some wickedly compelling reason to include it. By 'non-trivially,' I mean that I do not want converging series, integrals, etc. where it is obvious that #(start)# #(v!c,v!π,n,-)# #(v!c,v!π,n)# #(v!π,!0,n)# #(v!π,!0)# #(end)# or #(start)# #(v!c,v!π,n,-)# #(v!c,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# with #(start)# #(v!c,∈,n,-)# #(v!c,∈,n)# #(∈,v!ℚ,n,n)# #(∈,v!ℚ,n)# #(v!ℚ,!0,nn)# #(v!ℚ,!0)# #(end)# can simply be 'factored out' in some way such that it looks like #(start)# #(v!c,v!π,n,-)# #(v!c,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# was included after-the-fact so that said series, integral, etc. would equal #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!π,n,-)# #(f!,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,-)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!6,u,-)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,!0,u)# #(n!6,!0)# #(end)#. For instance, #(start)# #(∑,f!,n,-)# #(∑,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],n)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,=,n,n)# #(f!,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!π,n,nnn)# #(f!,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,nnnn)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnnna)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!6,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,!0,nnnu)# #(n!6,!0)# #(f!,v!π,o,n)# #(f!,v!π,o)# #(v!π,n!2,a,no)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,noa)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nnna,oa,n}# #{n!2,nnna,oa}# #{v!π,nnn,o,n}# #{v!π,nnn,o}# #(f!,n!6,u,n)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,⋅,n,nu)# #(n!6,⋅,n)# #(⋅,n!2,n,nun)# #(⋅,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!n,a,nunn)# #(n!2,v!n,a)# #(v!n,!0,nunna)# #(v!n,!0)# #{n!2,nnna,unn,n}# #{n!2,nnna,unn}# #{n!2,oa,unn,n}# #{n!2,oa,unn}# #{n!6,nnu,u,n}# #{n!6,nnu,u}# #{f!,nn,n}# #{f!,nn}# #(end)#, but clearly the appearance of #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!π,n,-)# #(f!,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,-)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!6,u,-)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,!0,u)# #(n!6,!0)# #(end)# here is contrived. (But, if you have an answer that seems very interesting but you're unsure if it fits the 'non-trivial' bill, keep in mind that nobody will actually stop you from posting it.)   I hope this is specific enough. This was my attempt at formally saying 'I want to see all the interesting ways we can make #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!π,n,-)# #(f!,v!π,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a,n)# #(v!π,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,na)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,-)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!6,u,-)# #(f!,n!6,u)# #(n!6,!0,u)# #(n!6,!0)# #(end)#.' With all that being said, I will give my favorite example as an answer below! :#(start)# #(),!0,-)# #(),!0)# #(end)#    There used to be a chunk of text explaining why this question should be reopened here. It was reopened, so I removed it.

title: Why do we have to factorize the function before taking its limit
body: I am learning about limits and there is something that I cant quite understand:  If we have the function:     #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!x,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,o)# #(v!x,[n,a],nnno)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,-,n,nnno)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nnnon)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,3n1o2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!x,n!2,a,nnno)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnnoa)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,v!x,u,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,u)# #(v!x,-,n,nnnu)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nnnun)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,3n1u2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,onn,unn,nnn}# #{n!1,onn,unn}# #{-,on,un,nnn}# #{-,on,un}# #{v!x,o,u,nnn}# #{v!x,o,u}# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nno,w,n}# #{v!x,nno,w}# #{v!x,nnu,w,n}# #{v!x,nnu,w}# #(end)#   Let's say that we want to see which value for y (image) the function approaches as x (domain) gets closer to 1. On a nutshell, we have to take this following limit:     #(start)# #(lim,[n,u],-)# #(lim,[n,u])# #(lim,f!,n,-)# #(lim,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],n)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!x,o,n)# #(f!,v!x,o)# #(v!x,[n,a],no)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,-,n,no)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,non)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nonn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!x,n!2,a,no)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,noa)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,v!x,u,n)# #(f!,v!x,u)# #(v!x,-,n,nu)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nun)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nunn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,onn,unn,n}# #{n!1,onn,unn}# #{-,on,un,n}# #{-,on,un}# #{v!x,o,u,n}# #{v!x,o,u}# #(lim,v!x,u,-)# #(lim,v!x,u)# #(v!x,→,n,u)# #(v!x,→,n)# #(→,n!1,n,un)# #(→,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,unn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,nonn,unn,-}# #{n!1,nonn,unn}# #{n!1,nunn,unn,-}# #{n!1,nunn,unn}# #{v!x,no,u,-}# #{v!x,no,u}# #{v!x,nu,u,-}# #{v!x,nu,u}# #(end)#   As soon as we look to this function, we realize that the function is not continuous at x = 1 (By the way, can I say that?).   I know the algorithm to figure out the solution of the limit:  First, there is the need of eliminating the function discontinuity. Usually, it is just a matter of factorizing the function into a new function which the exactly same image as the one before with one crucial difference: The function is continuous for all real numbers   My doubts:Is my way to think about it correct? Can I think like that?  Take the example above:       #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!x,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,o)# #(v!x,[n,a],nnno)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,-,n,nnno)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nnnon)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,3n1o2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!x,n!2,a,nnno)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnnoa)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,v!x,u,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,u)# #(v!x,-,n,nnnu)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nnnun)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,3n1u2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,onn,unn,nnn}# #{n!1,onn,unn}# #{-,on,un,nnn}# #{-,on,un}# #{v!x,o,u,nnn}# #{v!x,o,u}# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nno,w,n}# #{v!x,nno,w}# #{v!x,nnu,w,n}# #{v!x,nnu,w}# #(end)#   After factorizing, we get:  #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!x,n,nn)# #(=,v!x,n)# #(v!x,+,n,nnn)# #(v!x,+,n)# #(+,n!1,n,nnnn)# #(+,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nnnnn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nn,w,n}# #{v!x,nn,w}# #(end)#  If we plot both functions, they are the same, although the second one has its continuity all along the real numbers domain  Thanks in advance

title: Formal relationship between rules of inference and the material conditional
body: I am not #(start)# #(n!100,%,n,-)# #(n!100,%,n)# #(%,!0,n)# #(%,!0)# #(end)# clear as to what constitutes the difference between a rule of inference and the material conditional, at least in classical logic. I am using the truth-functional definition of the material conditional, commonly visualised through its truth table, but I'm not entirely sure what the formal definition of a rule of inference is. The wikipedia article defines it to be a particular kind of logical form, which seems to be a term from philosophical logic that I'm not familiar with, but reading that article didn't really answer my question. It pertains more to the mathematical side of things, and I am specifically interested in the interplay between the concepts on the syntactic and semantic level. As far as I can tell, any rule of inference can be 'captured' by a corresponding material conditional: if we take modus ponens as a well-known example, what is the difference between #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,→,n,-)# #(m!()1x1,→,n)# #(→,v!b,n,n)# #(→,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,∧,n,w)# #(v!a,∧,n)# #(∧,m!()1x1,n,wn)# #(∧,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,wnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,→,n,wnnw)# #(v!a,→,n)# #(→,v!b,n,wnnwn)# #(→,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,1w2n1w2n)# #(v!b,!0)# #{v!b,nn,1w2n1w2n,-}# #{v!b,nn,1w2n1w2n}# #{→,n,wnnwn,-}# #{→,n,wnnwn}# #{v!a,nnw,w}# #{v!a,nnw}# #{m!()1x1,wnn,-}# #{m!()1x1,wnn}# #(end)# and #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!qvar_$,n,-)# #(f!,v!qvar_$,n)# #(v!qvar_$,!0,n)# #(v!qvar_$,!0)# #(f!,v!a,o,-)# #(f!,v!a,o)# #(v!a,→,n,o)# #(v!a,→,n)# #(→,v!b,n,on)# #(→,v!b,n)# #(v!b,comma,n,onn)# #(v!b,comma,n)# #(comma,v!a,n,onnn)# #(comma,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,onnnn)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nnnn,o}# #{v!a,nnnn}# #(f!,v!b,u,-)# #(f!,v!b,u)# #(v!b,!0,u)# #(v!b,!0)# #{v!b,onn,u,-}# #{v!b,onn,u}# #(end)# On a functional level, both statements seem to be expressing the same thing. What determines the need to use two separate terms and notations, and what, if anything, separates them?

body: This might be silly, but here it goes.  Let #(start)# #(v!p,comma,n,-)# #(v!p,comma,n)# #(comma,v!s,n,n)# #(comma,v!s,n)# #(v!s,gt,n,nn)# #(v!s,gt,n)# #(gt,n!0,n,nnn)# #(gt,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nnnn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(end)# be positive real numbers that satisfy #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,≥,n,-)# #(f!,≥,n)# #(≥,r!,n,n)# #(≥,r!,n)# #(r!,[c,w],nn)# #(r!,[c,w])# #(r!,v!n,c,nn)# #(r!,v!n,c)# #(v!n,!0,nnc)# #(v!n,!0)# #(r!,v!p,w,nn)# #(r!,v!p,w)# #(v!p,!0,nnw)# #(v!p,!0)# #(f!,v!s,o,-)# #(f!,v!s,o)# #(v!s,!0,o)# #(v!s,!0)# #(f!,v!n,u,-)# #(f!,v!n,u)# #(v!n,!0,u)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nnc,u,-}# #{v!n,nnc,u}# #(end)#.     Does there exist a sequence of positive real numbers #(start)# #(v!a,[n,b],-)# #(v!a,[n,b])# #(v!a,comma,n,-)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!…,n,n)# #(comma,v!…,n)# #(v!…,comma,n,nn)# #(v!…,comma,n)# #(comma,v!a,n,nnn)# #(comma,v!a,n)# #(v!a,v!n,b,nnnn)# #(v!a,v!n,b)# #(v!n,!0,nnnnb)# #(v!n,!0)# #{comma,nn,n}# #{comma,nn}# #(v!a,n!1,b,-)# #(v!a,n!1,b)# #(n!1,!0,b)# #(n!1,!0)# #{v!a,nnnn,-}# #{v!a,nnnn}# #(end)# such that #(start)# #(v!s,=,n,-)# #(v!s,=,n)# #(=,∑,n,n)# #(=,∑,n)# #(∑,v!a,n,nn)# #(∑,v!a,n)# #(v!a,[n,b],nnn)# #(v!a,[n,b])# #(v!a,comma,n,nnn)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!p,n,nnnn)# #(comma,v!p,n)# #(v!p,=,n,nnnnn)# #(v!p,=,n)# #(=,∏,n,6n)# #(=,∏,n)# #(∏,v!a,n,7n)# #(∏,v!a,n)# #(v!a,v!i,b,8n)# #(v!a,v!i,b)# #(v!i,!0,8n1b)# #(v!i,!0)# #(v!a,v!i,b,nnn)# #(v!a,v!i,b)# #(v!i,!0,nnnb)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,5n1b,b,nnn}# #{v!i,5n1b,b}# #{v!a,nnnnn,nnn}# #{v!a,nnnnn}# #{=,nnnnn,n}# #{=,nnnnn}# #(end)#?   Clearly, #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,≥,n,-)# #(f!,≥,n)# #(≥,r!,n,n)# #(≥,r!,n)# #(r!,[c,w],nn)# #(r!,[c,w])# #(r!,v!n,c,nn)# #(r!,v!n,c)# #(v!n,!0,nnc)# #(v!n,!0)# #(r!,v!p,w,nn)# #(r!,v!p,w)# #(v!p,!0,nnw)# #(v!p,!0)# #(f!,v!s,o,-)# #(f!,v!s,o)# #(v!s,!0,o)# #(v!s,!0)# #(f!,v!n,u,-)# #(f!,v!n,u)# #(v!n,!0,u)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nnc,u,-}# #{v!n,nnc,u}# #(end)# is a necessary condition, due to the AM-GM inequality. A friend of mine asserted this without giving any examples. I seriously doubt it, but I had hard time trying to disprove it since analysis isn't really my thing. I can't even think of any class of differentiable functions with #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,⊆,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,⊆,n)# #(⊆,v!ℚ,n,nn)# #(⊆,v!ℚ,n)# #(v!ℚ,!0,nnn)# #(v!ℚ,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!ℚ,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!ℚ,w)# #(v!ℚ,!0,nw)# #(v!ℚ,!0)# #{v!ℚ,nn,w,n}# #{v!ℚ,nn,w}# #(end)# other than the rational functions.

For instance in order to calculate the optimal amount of ripple adders so as to minimise the execution time of the addition process: #(start)# #(t!executiontime,m!()1x2,n,-)# is the number of bits in the numbers to add, #(start)# #(v!k,!0,-)# #(v!k,!0)# #(end)# is the amount of adders in ripple and #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# is the "delta gate" (the time that takes to a gate to operate). Clearly you can see that the execution time function is not continuous at all because #(start)# #(v!k,!0,-)# #(v!k,!0)# #(end)# is a natural number and so is #(start)# #(v!n,!0,-)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)#. This is driving me crazy because on the one hand I understand that I can analyse the function as a continuous one and get results in that way, and indeed I think that's what we do ("I think", that's why I am asking), but my intuition and knowledge about mathematical analysis tells me that this is completely wrong, because the truth is that the function is not continuous and will never be and because of that, the derivative with respect to #(start)# #(v!k,!0,-)# #(v!k,!0)# #(end)# or #(start)# #(v!n,!0,-)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# does not exist because there is no rate of change. title: Why is there no hyper-hypercohomology?
body: I am looking for a reference to answer the question in the title. Let me try to clarify a little what I mean:  If a single sheaf #(start)# #(v!ℱ,!0,-)# #(v!ℱ,!0)# #(end)# has a resolution #(start)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a,-)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,a)# #(∙,!0)# #(end)# by not necessarily injective objects, then the usual cohomology of #(start)# #(v!ℱ,!0,-)# #(v!ℱ,!0)# #(end)# is isomorphic to the hypercohomology of #(start)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a,-)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,a)# #(∙,!0)# #(end)#:  #(start)# #(v!h,[n,a],-)# #(v!h,[n,a])# #(v!h,m!()1x2,n,-)# #(v!h,m!()1x2,n)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w])# #(m!()1x2,≅,n,n)# #(m!()1x2,≅,n)# #(≅,v!ℍ,n,nn)# #(≅,v!ℍ,n)# #(v!ℍ,[n,a],nnn)# #(v!ℍ,[n,a])# #(v!ℍ,m!()1x2,n,nnn)# #(v!ℍ,m!()1x2,n)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w],nnnn)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w])# #(m!()1x2,.,n,nnnn)# #(m!()1x2,.,n)# #(.,!0,nnnnn)# #(.,!0)# #(m!()1x2,v!x,w,nnnn)# #(m!()1x2,v!x,w)# #(v!x,v!𝒢,e,nnnnw)# #(v!x,v!𝒢,e)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a,4n1w1e)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,4n1w1e1a)# #(∙,!0)# #(v!ℍ,v!i,a,nnn)# #(v!ℍ,v!i,a)# #(v!i,!0,nnna)# #(v!i,!0)# #(m!()1x2,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x2,v!x,w)# #(v!x,v!ℱ,e,nw)# #(v!x,v!ℱ,e)# #(v!ℱ,!0,nwe)# #(v!ℱ,!0)# #{v!x,nnnw,w,n}# #{v!x,nnnw,w}# #{m!()1x2,nnn,n}# #{m!()1x2,nnn}# #(v!h,v!i,a,-)# #(v!h,v!i,a)# #(v!i,!0,a)# #(v!i,!0)# #{v!i,nnna,a,-}# #{v!i,nnna,a}# #(end)#  Now, if one was starting with a complex of sheaves #(start)# #(v!ℱ,∙,a,-)# #(v!ℱ,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,a)# #(∙,!0)# #(end)# and a "resolution" thereof, i.e. a complex of complexes #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[a,w])# #(m!()1x1,∙,a,-)# #(m!()1x1,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,a)# #(∙,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!𝒢,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,v!𝒢,w)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a,w)# #(v!𝒢,∙,a)# #(∙,!0,wa)# #(∙,!0)# #{∙,a,wa,-}# #{∙,a,wa}# #(end)#, then one should touch on a concept that could be called hyper-hypercohomology.   Yet, I never heard of its existence and I'm pretty sure it does not give you anything new, as soon as you work in the derived category. I just find myself unable to pin down why exactly this is the case.   Any ideas anyone?

title: Uniformly continuous or not?
body: So I supposed to find out if #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!1,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,u)# #(n!1,+,n,nnnu)# #(n!1,+,n)# #(+,v!ln,n,nnnun)# #(+,v!ln,n)# #(v!ln,[n,a],3n1u2n)# #(v!ln,[n,a])# #(v!ln,v!x,n,3n1u2n)# #(v!ln,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,3n1u3n)# #(v!x,!0)# #(v!ln,n!2,a,3n1u2n)# #(v!ln,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,3n1u2n1a)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!1,o,u,nnn}# #{n!1,o,u}# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,2n1u3n,w,n}# #{v!x,2n1u3n,w}# #(end)# is uniformly continuous on #(start)# #(v!i,=,n,-)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,m!()1x2,n,n)# #(=,m!()1x2,n)# #(m!()1x2,n!0,w,nn)# #(m!()1x2,n!0,w)# #(n!0,v!∞,e,nnw)# #(n!0,v!∞,e)# #(v!∞,!0,nnwe)# #(v!∞,!0)# #(end)# So I have been thinking a lot. Could I say that #(start)# #(v!f,!0,-)# #(v!f,!0)# #(end)# is continuous on #(start)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x2,n!0,w,-)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x2,n!0,w)# #(n!0,n!1,e,w)# #(n!0,n!1,e)# #(n!1,!0,we)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# and therefore uniformly continuous here? Or is this not valid, because #(start)# #(v!ln,!0,-)# #(v!ln,!0)# #(end)# is not defined at #(start)# #(v!x,=,n,-)# #(v!x,=,n)# #(=,n!0,n,n)# #(=,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(end)#?
